data.text: Contents

Appendix 2: Button gastrostomy tubes - local guidance for balloon gastrostomy ................ 8 Appendix 3: Replacing water in a balloon gastrostomy ....................................................... 9 Appendix 4: What to do if your tube comes out ................................................................. 10
Introduction

There is a Home Enteral Feeding contract across Mid and South Essex. In order for clinical care to be carried out by the home care company, in accordance with the agreed pathways, the guidance has to be ratified across all 3 organisations. These guidelines have been developed by the Nutrition Nurses, based on evidence where possible.
Enteral feeding tubes consist of:
Nasogastric feeding tubes;
Nasojejunal feeding tubes;
Jejunostomy;
Gastrostomy feeding tubes;
Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG);
Balloon gastrostomy either placed endoscopically or percutaneously.
For the purpose of this document only gastrostomy clinical guidelines will be included.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to have a consistent approach to clinical care of enterally fed patients in the community
Definitions

table_items.text: A hospital based Clinical Nurse Specialist in Basildon, Southend or Broomfield Hospital
A feeding tube placed into the stomach that is retained by a disc or other device, excluding a balloon
A feeding tube placed into the stomach that is held in placed by a water filled balloon

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Nutrition Nurse Specialist – to ensure these guidelines are available and followed for outpatient adults with enteral feeding tubes.
Community Registered Nurse – to use these guidelines to advise and inform practice.
Homecare Enteral Feeding Contract Nurse – to use these guidelines to advise and inform practice.
Registered Dietitian – to use these guidelines to advise and inform practice.
Key elements of guideline
All guidance is contained within the appendices.
Training requirements
Home Enteral Feeding company nurses will undertake training to competence through their own governance structure. These guidelines will be used in addition to home care company guidelines.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Quality & Performance Review Group (QPRG) for the Home Enteral Feeding contract overseen by Thurrock CCG
QPRG Nutrition Support team at each hospital
Lead Nutrition Nurse at each hospital Lead Dietitian at each hospital

data.text: Approval and Implementation

These guidelines will be approved locally at each hospital within the Trust. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group. Implementation will be supported by Thurrock CCG.
It is the author's responsibility to inform Thurrock CCG, Fresenius Kabi nurses and the community nurses of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 7)
Appendix 1: Balloon gastrostomy tubes - local guidance for balloon volume replacement 2019

table_items.text: External tube failure Balloon failure When weekly balloon volume is less than 1/ 2 placed for 2 consecutive weeks
2-3mls to 5mls Check balloon volume before use
External tube failure Balloon failure When weekly balloon volume is less than 1/2 placed for 2 consecutive weeks
External tube failure Balloon failure When weekly balloon volume is less than 1/2 placed for 2 consecutive weeks
External tube failure Balloon failure When weekly balloon volume is less than 1/2 placed for 2 consecutive weeks

data.text: Use cooled boiled water for balloons. Never use air as it is lost rapidly from the balloon and the tube will fall out.
THIS INFORMATION IS CORRECT AT THE TIME OF PUBLICATION BUT SHOULD ALWAYS BE CHECKED AGAINST THE MANUFACTURER'S GUIDANCE WHICH MAY CHANGE
Written & agreed by Sam Wilson, Nutrition Nurse Specialist Southend Hospital and Andrea Cartwright, Consultant Nurse – Nutrition Support Basildon Hospital

Appendix 3: Replacing water in a balloon gastrostomy
Replacing water in balloon gastrostomy tube: A guide for patients
This should only be done after 14 days following placement or earlier if on advice from the Nutrition Nurse Specialist
Your balloon tube needs topping up weekly / monthly / ……………. Delete as appropriate
Equipment
Clean hands
2 x 5ml syringe (white / clear) ___ mls cooled boiled water
1 x 50ml enteral feeding syringe pH testing strips
Instructions
Get ready a clean surface
Wash and dry hands thoroughly
Open both syringes
Draw up ___ mls cooled boiled water into one syringe
Aspirate enteral feeding tube and test pH – this is to compare with post balloon check. Record the pH for later.
Hold tube under the retention bolster (next to the skin) to prevent the tube moving while you pull the retention bolster backwards to the end of the tube
Advance tube about 3 - 5cm into the stomach
Attach the empty syringe to the balloon inflation valve (usually marked ‘Bal')
Unclamp the tube (if not already unclamped)
Draw back the water in the syringe (you should get between1 and 5 mls), make note of the volume
Remove the syringe from the balloon inflation valve and put down
Pick up the syringe with the cooled boiled water in and attach to the ‘Bal' balloon inflation port and inject the water into the balloon
Remove the empty syringe
Clean around the gastrostomy site (as directed)
Pull the tube back, until you can feel it against your fingers on the abdomen
Push the retention bolster / disk back down the tube until it is against to abdomen (as previously shown)
Recheck pH of aspirate to make sure you are still in the stomach
Dispose of syringes
Appendix 4: What to do if your tube comes out
What to do if your tube comes out
Don't panic! Wash your hands
If the gastrostomy falls out and the balloon is still inflated, take a syringe and place in the balloon inflation port and take out the water.
Pull the retention bolster disc up the tube as far as possible (as near to the inflation valve as possible).

When the balloon is flat replace it into the stomach and push in as far as it will go, and tape into place. You are now preserving the tract whilst you can get everything else ready. Take the side clamp off the old tube if you have one to use on the new tube.

If you feel happy to replace the tube, continue; if you are unsure or not happy seek advice. Contact the FK Homecare line in work hours 0808 100 1990, or out of hours contact the Community Nurse or attend the Emergency Department at your local hospital taking your spare tube and these instructions with you.
You should have a spare tube at home, make sure that someone orders you a new one when one is used.
Get ready a clean surface to open out equipment. You will need:-
- the new tube
- a 50 ml syringe
- a pair of gloves
- __ mls of cooled boiled water
- pH testing strips
- the dressing for afterwards
Draw up the water into the syringe ready for when the tube is in (if not already in the pack)
Open the tube package and pull the retention bolster to the end of the tube
Open the gloves.
Wash your hands and put on the gloves.
Take out the old tube.
Take the new tube and place into the tract and push in as far as possible.
Take the pre-filled syringe and put into the balloon inflation valve and inflate the balloon.

Once inflated, check the pH of the aspirate fluid using a 50ml syringe. Apply the fliud to the test strip and read it. If the pH is 5.5 or below it is safe to use, if it is not, or you have concerns seek advice
Pull the tube back until there is some tension, clean around the exit site, re-dress and replace the retention bolster / skin disc to its normal position.
Replace the clamp if you have one
Designed February 2019, revised June 2019 Reviewed June 2020
Review June 2021
Appendix 5: Advice sheet for community and fresenius- kabi nurses for when gastrostomy is leaking

table_items.text: Is it a new tube? <48 hrs
Refer to GP/out of hrs GP. Follow NPSA Alert Guidance
Is the site wet, leaking & requiring >daily dressings ?
Test pH of fluid to see if it is gastric contents Swab site to rule out infection
Does water/foo d leak when tube is being used
Is it a significant bleed? Soak through a dressing in <1hr
Has it been pulled/tugged ? Watch & ob serve for 2 hrs. if bleeding continues seek advice as above
Recommend PPI & prokinetic unless contraindicated . Make sure the tube advances & rotates daily. Provide a skin barrier. Tighten skin disk but make sure it is loosened at least twice daily
Lubricate the tube with water or water soluble gel. Put 200mls air down the tube to inflate the stomach, try to advance & rotate the tube. If this doesn't work ask GP to refer in for ax
Is the tube buried? Refer to GP?
Is there overgranulation tissue? Commence the granuloma pathway
If swab positive ask GP to prescribe antibiotics / anti fungal treatment
Could this be ascetic fluid? Ask GP to refer in for ax
Tighten the external disk to get a seal (put foam dressing underneath for comfort). Loosen twice daily. Ensure tube is advanced & rotated daily. If no improvementin 1 week ask GP to refer for ax.
If bleeding is significant, but continues with no apparent cause, GP should refer into hospital for specialist advice

data.text: Appendix 6: Granuloma pathway
Gastrostomy Granuloma Pathway – Adults

table_items.text: (Please affix Hospital Sticker) Name Address Post Code Date of Birth NHS number

data.text: A granuloma is a mass of inflamed granulation tissue usually associated with ulcerated infections. To prevent or treat granuloma's the following pathway should be instigated.
When to swab a gastrostomy exit site: – if erythema, tenderness, purulent discharge, pain, swelling, malodour, elevated temperature or a combination of all.

table_items.text: Does patient have CKD stage 3 or worse?
If yes, salt treatment is not appropriate so omit first & second line treatments

data.text: Date pathway instigated:  Referral from:

table_items.text: Standard Treatment Observe the site. Open the fixator and clean area. Octenillin® wash daily for 1 minute, ensure site is allowed to dry before applying a dressing. Swab if infection clinically suspected. Tighten fixator and ensure it is snug (2mm) from the exit site.

First-line treatment Use a barrier cream or spray on healthy skin. Use ½ teaspoon of regular table salt and sprinkle it onto the granuloma. Leave for 10 minutes then wash off thoroughly. Apply foam dressing if necessary. REPEAT DAILY FOR 7 DAYS

Second-line treatment Follow first line treatment as above. Once the salt soak has been washed off, clean the site with Octenillin® and apply Octenillin® soaks for 10 minutes daily. Then dress with AMD and square foam dressing as above. Tighten fixator and ensure it is snug (2mm) from the exit site. Change dressing daily. REPEAT DAILY FOR 2 WEEKS

Third-line treatment Clean with Octenillin® as above. Apply Aquacel ag or Durafiber ag silver dressing (10cm x 10cm) on the granuloma (do not cut the dressing). Apply double layer of square foam dressing. Tighten fixator and ensure it is snug (2mm) from the exit site. Replace as required. REVIEW AFTER 2 WEEKS

Fourth line treatment Clean with Octenillin® as above. Apply 1% hydrocortisone cream daily for one week. Apply double layer foam dressing. Tighten fixator and ensure it is snug (2mm) from the exit site. Change dressing daily. REVIEW AFTER 1 WEEK
Refer to Nutrition Nurse Specialist – follow usual referral pathway Basildon Hospital 01268 593112 Southend Hospital 01702 385424 Broomfield Hospital 01245 516146 x 6146

data.text: Octenillin® Wound Irrigation Solution

Octenillin® is a wound irrigating solution that cleanses, moistens and decontaminates wounds. It removes wound crusts and loosens the biofilm, therefore reducing microorganisms. The bottle once open, is for single patient use and can be used for 8 weeks.
Authors
Samantha Wilson, Nutrition Nurse Specialist, Southend University Hospital NHSFT
Andrea Cartwright, Consultant Nurse Nutrition Support, Basildon University Hospital NHSFT August 2016, December 2018 Review 2023
